results.title: Bringing his spirit back home
results.creator_credit: Dot Peters, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dot Peters’ father was 39 when he joined World War II. He fought in the Middle East and was later captured in Java and sent to a Prisoner of War camp in Japan. He died there, leaving a grieving family wondering what he went through. Simultaneously, they witnessed the injustices inflicted on fellow Indigenous servicemen who had experienced equality overseas, only to find it stripped away on their return. This inspired Dot to dedicate the rest of her life to fighting for Indigenous rights, eventually collaborating with the Shrine of Remembrance to recognise the contribution made by Indigenous people during the war. This fight has helped her to bring her father’s spirit home, to bestow upon his memory a sense of belonging, recognition and honour.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dot Peters, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Youngest WAAAF in the service
results.creator_credit: Jean Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: For Jean Williamson, her time at the Women’s Auxiliary Australian Airforce was new and exciting and, much to her disappointment, short. She joined a few months shy of the end of the war. Still, as she looks back through an album of memories, she reflects fondly on friends made, good times and meeting her husband Noel. She also considers how at that time she wasn’t aware she was an Indigenous Australian. When she found out, she responded by becoming heavily involved in the Indigenous community. Despite her pale complexion, Jean Williamson proudly declares her black heart.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

She also considers how at that time she wasn’t aware she was an Indigenous Australian. When she found out, she responded by becoming heavily involved in the Indigenous community. Despite her pale complexion, Jean Williamson proudly declares her black heart.

results.title: A Turning point
results.creator_credit: Noel Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Noel Williamson joined the RAAF because he wanted adventure and he wanted to serve. While his limited education kept him grounded, he speaks fondly of his time in the RAAF, and the opportunities that he grasped with both hands once the war ended.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Noel Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Letters from Java
results.brief_description: Eric Peters only knew his dad through what records were left behind. They were mostly letters that came through the censors at a POW camp in Burma and old photos. He reflects on the sadness of not knowing his dad and the importance of bringing his spirit home to rest.
results.description: Eric Peters only knew his dad through what records were left behind. They were mostly letters that came through the censors at a POW camp in Burma and old photos. He reflects on the sadness of not knowing his dad and the importance of bringing his spirit home to rest.

results.title: An Interview with Harry Barkla
results.brief_description: Harry Barkla was part of the 39th Battalion, made up mostly of Chocolate (Chocco) soldiers. They were called this because it was thought that they would melt in the sun, that they wouldn’t know how to fight. In Kokoda, they soon proved themselves and Harry talks about some of the horrific experiences he went through that were typical of this war. These are some of his memories that he has tried to forget but never can. Even if you didn’t know someone’s name in the 39th Battalion, you still called them mate and you never forget your mates.

results.title: Hope
results.creator_credit: Leslie Jones, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Les Jones heard those two magic words “It’s over”, he starting thinking about his future after the war. The middle of three generations of army men, he was part of the last major action in the Pacific part of World War II. As well as being uncertain about his future, Les also thought about those that wouldn’t be returning with him. It is with the thoughts of these lost soldiers in mind, that Les considers war and whether or not there is a better way to solve conflict.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Leslie Jones, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Why two numbers
results.creator_credit: Jayne Mooney, Noel O'Brien, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: The O’Brien family have served in the army since the 1800s. Noel O’Brien, himself a member of the service, delves into the military history of his family and, in particular, of his father. Francis Charles O’Brien had two regimental numbers to his name and Noel wanted to find out the reason. As a result, he discovers something of his father’s personality, a larrikin who got himself into trouble, but was courageous enough to always be there for his mates.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jayne Mooney, Noel O’Brien, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

group_siblings.title: When war came to Australia

results.title: When war came to Australia
results.creator_credit: Bill Hosking, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A recent visit to Darwin with his son reminded Bill Hosking of the time that war came to Australia. As one of the men who defended Darwin during that time, he was instructed to keep the details of the attack secret. In 1942, Bill Hosking joined up and was shipped up to train in the Northern Territory. It was during this time that the air raids on Darwin took place. Bill shares his experiences because he believes that not many people today know the story of how Australia came under attack.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Hosking, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

description_for_label: A recent visit to Darwin with his son reminded Bill Hosking of the time that war came to Australia. As one of the men who defended Darwin during that time, he was instructed to keep the details of the attack secret. In 1942, Bill Hosking joined up and was shipped up to train in the Northern Territory. It was during this time that the air raids on Darwin took place. Bill shares his experiences because he believes that not many people today know the story of how Australia came under attack.
